headline: Arkansas finance official says state won’t pay corrections board legal fees
summary: The Department of Finance and Administration refused to pay a $300,000 legal bill for the Board of Corrections, citing violations of state procurement law and the constitution. DFA Secretary Jim Hudson stated the Department of Corrections lacks appropriated funds for the expense, which would require legislative approval under the state constitution. This decision further escalates the two-year power struggle between the board and Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders over control of the state's prison system.

headline: Hospital in South Arkansas closes maternity ward, adding to region’s shortage
summary: The closure of Ouachita County Medical Center's labor and delivery unit—the seventh rural Arkansas closure since 2020—exacerbates the state's maternal health crisis, forcing pregnant patients to travel 40-60 minutes and increasing ambulance births. Hospital administrators cited financial infeasibility and staffing challenges, while the Arkansas Hospital Association blamed inadequate reimbursement rates. Arkansas already suffers among the nation's highest maternal and infant mortality rates. The hospital's application for federal "rural emergency hospital" status—which eliminates inpatient beds—highlights policy tensions between financial sustainability and comprehensive obstetric care. State Sen. Matt Stone warned the closure will worsen infant mortality and maternal outcomes, underscoring the rural public health emergency.

headline: Protestors march in downtown Denver to protest fatal ICE shooting
summary: Hundreds gathered at Denver's Capitol Friday to protest the ICE shooting of Colorado Springs native Renee Good in Minneapolis, with activist Jeanette Vizguerra leading a march that closed roads toward Union Station. Governor Jared Polis called for a federal investigation as demonstrators alleged a cover-up. Additional protests are planned this weekend at Centennial's ICE office, continuing opposition to federal immigration enforcement.

headline: Hudson prison under contract to become Colorado’s newest ICE detention center
summary: The Trump administration awarded The GEO Group a contract on December 1, 2025, to operate the dormant Hudson Correctional Facility as an ICE detention center, expanding Colorado's capacity by 1,200 beds as part of the president's mass deportation plan; the facility is one of three new sites that would triple the state's detention capacity, while the ACLU of Colorado criticized the government's heavy redactions of procurement documents and called for transparency in spending federal immigration detention funds allocated by Congress.

headline: ICE killing of driver involved tactics many police departments warn against − but not ICE itself
summary: The fatal shooting of Renee Nicole Good by an ICE officer in Minneapolis has renewed scrutiny of ICE's use-of-force policy, which lacks the Department of Justice's explicit instruction for officers to avoid moving vehicles when feasible, contradicting President Biden's 2022 executive order requiring federal agencies to meet or exceed DOJ standards, and demonstrating a persistent gap between immigration enforcement policy and life-protecting best practices.

headline: For many Missouri families, any tax cut will be swallowed by rising health care costs
summary: Missouri faces a $400 million revenue shortfall largely due to a capital gains tax exemption costing $500 million annually, while Governor Kehoe proposes eliminating the state's $8.7 billion income tax that funds two-thirds of general revenue for schools, Medicaid, mental health care, and child protection; despite a historic $8 billion surplus in June 2023, one-time reserves cannot offset permanent revenue losses, Kansas's experience warns aggressive tax cuts erode state finances, and leaders have not specified what services would be cut or how to replace the lost revenue.

headline: Torrance County ICE contract extension ‘likely improper and invalid,’ NMDOJ says
summary: The New Mexico Department of Justice determined Torrance County's ICE detention contract extension was "likely improper and invalid" due to potential Open Meetings Act violations and improper backdating. The county provided only one day's notice instead of the required 72 hours for the December 30 meeting and backdated the contract to November 1, 2025. The agreement allows ICE to house immigrant detainees at the Torrance County Detention Facility through March 31, 2026, at $2.4 million monthly. County Commission Chair Ryan Schwebach denied any violations and said the county attorney is drafting a response. The dispute underscores heightened state scrutiny of local immigration enforcement contracting and procurement compliance.

headline: Protestors, ICE clash at Albuquerque DHS facility
summary: Approximately 20 protesters organized by Dare to Struggle New Mexico gathered outside Albuquerque's ICE office on Jan. 9, 2026, to demonstrate against the fatal shooting of Renee Good in Minnesota. DHS officials detained two protesters, shoved demonstrators onto sidewalks, deployed pepper spray, and declared the gathering an unlawful assembly. Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham had earlier expressed support for peaceful protest and called for a thorough investigation, creating policy tension between state leadership and federal enforcement actions.

headline: Republican-led Michigan House files lawsuit to disallow $645 million in work project spending
summary: The Republican-led Michigan House filed a lawsuit to block 31 state departments from accessing $645 million in work project spending after the House Appropriations Committee's party-line vote to disapprove the funds, a maneuver the Attorney General ruled unconstitutional; the suit seeks immediate injunctive relief to prevent the Whitmer administration from utilizing the funding.

headline: After ICE protest, Hartford police launch investigation
summary: A Hartford vigil protesting the killing of Renee Good by an ICE officer in Minnesota escalated into a confrontation with suspected federal agents, resulting in a hit-and-run, pepper-spray deployment, and property damage; Mayor Arulampalam, Gov. Lamont, and Sen. Blumenthal are investigating these incidents as potential crimes while condemning the Trump administration's immigration enforcement as lawless and provocative, and are urging peaceful protest despite federal actions that undermine local law enforcement cooperation and community safety.

headline: Renee Good, poet and mother of 3, was supporting neighbors when ICE shot her, wife says
summary: An ICE agent identified as Jonathan Ross fatally shot Renee Good in Minneapolis while she was supporting neighbors, raising immediate concerns about federal immigration enforcement tactics and community safety. The killing has sparked large-scale public mourning, with thousands attending a vigil and creating a memorial site. Good had recently moved from Kansas City to Minnesota following the 2024 election, underscoring how immigration enforcement policies affect residential choices and community stability.

headline: NC Bishop Barber condemns shooting by ICE agent, promotes Selma-like march for justice
summary: Bishop William Barber and a coalition of religious and advocacy organizations announced "This Is Our Selma," a memorial march from Wilson to Raleigh scheduled for February 11-14, 2026, responding to the fatal shooting of a mother by ICE and state policies including congressional redistricting that critics argue dilutes Black voting power, threats to Medicaid, and voting restrictions. The march aims to spotlight early voting for March 2026 primaries and empower eligible voters, including formerly incarcerated individuals who may be unaware of their voting rights. Organizers frame the event as a continuation of the fight for justice and democracy 156 years after the 15th Amendment's ratification. The coalition includes Repairers of the Breach, Indivisible, the North Carolina Council of Churches, the North Carolina Poor People's Campaign, and the Union of Southern Service Workers. The march will culminate in a "Time to Love Forward" mobilization in downtown Raleigh on February 14.

headline: Polk County faces more lawsuits initiated by ICE detainees
summary: The Trump administration's expanded "mandatory detention" policy denies ICE detainees bond hearings, a position rejected by over 300 federal judges in 1,600+ cases, yet DOJ continues appealing; Iowa counties face lawsuits from individuals detained during traffic stops and routine appointments, with Polk County housing 68 ICE detainees, challenging the policy's constitutionality and counties' complicity in indefinite federal immigration detention.
